President Steven Muller yesterda, issued an explanation and
apology for the exclusion of most
Hopkins undergraduates from
next week's Commemoration
Day proceedings.
The Commemoration Day
ceremony, which is to take place

great interest since the announcement that President George Bush
is likely to be the keynote
speaker. Hopkins will confer an
honorary doctoral degree on Bush
at the ceremony.
"I feel very badly for the
students at Homewood," said
Muller. "I have enormous sympathy for the way they must
feel...I really can't apologize, but
I do feel very apologetic."
Only one student from each
school of Hopkins has been invited to hear Bush speak in
person.
Muller attributed the lack of invitations
for
Hopkins

United States.

reached to either confirm or deny
Muller's statements.

centennial year of Hopkins
Medicine. In his letter of invitation to President Bush, Muller

Network counsels harrassment victims
by Priscilla O'Brian(
The Sexual Harassment Advisers Network is an informal
group of advisers that are there
to offer support. "We assist victims in exploring their options
and selecting one they are comfortable with and is most likely
to have the desired outcome. Our
main goal is bringing the offensive behavior to an end," said
Andrea Perry, director of
Residential Life and a member of
the Network.
The network uses an informal
resolution process,as its primary
role is as a support for the victim. According to Perry, "The
advisors are able to put victims
in touch with legal avenues and
make a referral to the appropriate
administrative office on campus
so that a formal complaint is
recorded."
"All the members of the Network have received some
training in the counseling of victims of harassment," according
to Perry. The main purpose of the
network "is to assist all members
of the [University] community
that feel that they have been sexually harassed or are uncertain
about whether they have been."
"The Network is very anxious
to publicize its existence and encourages members of the community who are confronting an

issue to take advantage of the support network," said Perry. She
went on to add, "Often times we
assist in figuring out whether or
not they have been harassed. In
many incidences, people are unsure if what has occurred is
harassment."
Sexual harassment is not
always as obvious as one would
believe. Harassment in the
university environment encompasses more than just requiring
sexual favors as a prerequisite for
academic success. It also comes
in many less blatant forms, including sexual teasing or jokes,
even slight physical contact.
Because sexual harassment does
come in many forms and varying
degrees, many people choose to
ignore it, fearing they may be
wrong; others are sure, but are
too embarrassed to talk with
anyone about it. According to
Perry, there is nothing to fear or
be embarrassed over; everyone
has the right to pursue their
education in a conducive atmosphere. In reporting sexual
harassment one is merely asserting the rights one has under
University policy as well as state
law.
The University has a strict
policy on sexual harassment: any
conduct "which creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive
learning or working environment

is prohibited. The University will
promptly investigate complaints
of sexual harassment and . . . will
institute disciplinary proceedings
against the offending individual."
Also, according to Perry,"The
Advisors Network is not primarily designed to help victims of
assault or rape." It is suggested
that if one is assaulted that one
contact either campus security or
the police immediately and seek
medical attention. There are
many victim assistance programs
in the area and, professional
counseling is also available on
campus at the White House.

(CPS)—Even as he called in his
Jan. 31 State of the Union Address to reform American
schools, President George Bush
proposed a federal budget that
would cause more than a million
collegians to lose all or part of
their financial aid, observers
maintained.
More than 300,000 students
would lose aid if two Bush budget
items—to kill the State Student
Incentive Grant (SSIG) program
and cut funding for Perkins Student Loans—pass.
Another 1.3 million students
would lose $200 Pell Grants or
have their grants cut by $50 if
Congress approves Bush's
proposals.
The president also proposed
cutting funding for the Stafford
Loan program, used by 3.7
million students this school year,
by $500 million, down to a total
of 3.3 billion.
Then, in his State of the Union
address, delivered hours after he
submitted a 3-inch thick book of
budget proposals to Congress, the
president urged schools to do better and to make U.S. students
"first in the world in math and
science" by the year 2000.

half of what is needed to keep up
with inflation. The proposed
budget will supply money to the
U.S. Department of Education,
which administers most federal
college programs, for the Oct. 1,
1990 through Sept. 30, 1991
fiscal year.

increase—to $1.9 billion—goes,

said, "I'm convinced that we are

The Community Assistants
on the Wolman Renovations
It has long been recognized that
the University has not established the concerns of undergraduate
life at Hopkins as its primary
focus. Recently, this prevailing
attitude has been made evident by
the minimal involvement of
University-owned apartment
residents in the decision making
process regarding University
apartment renovations. The committees set up to discuss these
renovations included administrators from the Offices of
Residential Life, Auxiliary Enterprises, Housing, Facilities
Management, and the Dean of
Students. Initially, when this
comprehensive committee met,
resident input was not effectively utilized. As far as can be
discerned, no appropriate resident
representatives were included in
the planning process. In fact, the
students on the original committee were chosen specifically
because they lived in off-campus
housing and were hand-picked by
the administration. As a result,
these students considered only the
disadvantages of living in University housing. In making changes
that affect resident life, those
students most directly affected
should have been consulted on a
much larger scale. Specifically,
students living in Universityowned apartments would have
been an ideal choice for additional student representation for
this comprehensive committee.
Community Assistants, working for the Housing Office and
the Office of Residential Life,
have as one of their major responsibilities the role of liason between the University-owned apartment residents and the administrators of the Homewood
campus for housing-related concerns. In light of this responssibility, it would have been appropriate to include Community
Assistants on the committee for
University apartment renovations. Because of this omission,
ideas form residents were not
considered. The following are
concerns relayed to Community

Assistants by current University
apartment residents with regards
to the soon-to-be-available Bradford Apartments.
(1) Students will be held
responsible for the entire apartment lease, paying per unit instead of the current method of
paying per bed.
(2) Eventual plans include forcing the tenant to commit to a
12-month lease instead of the current 9-month lease option.
(3) Students will be responsible for arranging their own
utilities. This will be an additional expense not accounted for
in the rent.
(4) Rental price estimates have
yet to be released for students and
their parents.
Some other concerns, in
general, about the proposed
University apartment renovations
are as follows:
(1) More apartment units
should have been designated as
single-occupancy dwellings.
(2) Attention should have been
paid more to the overall quality
of student life than to the maximum number of students housed together.
(3) The current question over
mandated versus guaranteed
sophomore housing in the
renovated Wolman and McCoy
Apartments should be answered
only after consulting students
most affected by the plans.
These are just a few of the ideas
that have yet to be addresses
satisfactorily. Future renovation
plans must resolve these issues.
Clearly student involvement at all
levels is crucial in planning for
resident life. It is not sufficient for
only students outside of University housing to participate in the
decision making process.

To the Editors:
In response to the article written by Rebecca Garron which appeared in the last issue of the
News-Letter: Ms. Garron states
that the intention of her discourse
is to defend the 2x +1 cartoon
from "misdirected, impassioned
criticism." She begins her
defense by questioning whether
or not the cartoon, a cartoon
which seeks to define a woman's
merit solely on the basis of her
sexual attractiveness, is sexist.
The call for "all hate mail"
scrawled beneath the cartoon
underscores the fact that the
author's primary intention was to
offend. Mr. Podurgiel requested
a response; I think he is getting
that for which he asked.
Ms. Garron goes on to
enumerate the responsibilities of
the Hopkins community. She
states that censorship in not the
answer. She is completely correct. To address the issue at hand.
when we, not the Women's
Group but for Hopkins students,
spoke to Dean Boswell, our intentions were as follows. We
wanted a letter to be distributed
to all students by Homewood
Deans stating that sexism should
not be tolerated on the campus.
Secondly, we wanted a meeting
arranged between the Spectator,
the GRO, and the concerned
students so that we could determine the positions of all involved, why the GRO allocated
University funds to support this
issue of the Spectator, and
whether the GRO was aware of
the cartoon in question.
It was not these four students
but Ms. Garron herself who calls
for the SAC to "pull its funding
from the Spectator." It seems that
Ms. Garron did not bother to
gather the correct information
before she began her tirade. Firstly, it was not a "special-interest
group" which filed the complaint
against the Spectator but four
students, two of whom were
unaffiliated. Secondly, the goal of
these students was not to stifle but
to draw out the issue of sexism.
Thirdly, the Spectator is not funded by the SAC but an outside
organization. It was granted funds
for only this issue by the GRO,
thus her call for SAC funding to
be denied, besides suggesting
censorship, is useless.
To continue with Ms. Garron's
list of reponsibilities: under item
number two, she attempts to shift
the "blame" for this cartoon
from the cartoonist to the Spectator. My questions to Rebecca
Garron: Is the Spectator some
amorphous mass? Is it not made
up of its contributors? Do they
have no responsibility for their
submissions?
The list is concluded with item

number three, in which Ms. Garron attempts to redefine the
definition of special interest
groups, claiming that all groups
should be dedicated to combatting
"all issues which divide the community." Perhaps Ms. Garron is
the only student who has the time
and energy to devote to every
issue on campus; the fact that
most students are busy with
classes, etc. is the reason why
responsibilities are divided.
Ms. Garron does make one
useful comment: "if we can't
eradicate prejudice in the containment of academia, we will be
unable to hinder its reproduction
in society at large." This is our
overall goal, not censorship, but
increased awareness and eventual
defeat of the prejudices that are
prevalent on the campus and in
society. Perhaps Ms. Garron and
others like her should stop to
assess the correct information
from "misdirected, impassioned
criticism."
Kelly King

Dear James
To the Editors:
At the risk of joining what I
think is a senseless enterprise, I
have a few things I'd like to bring
up.
Look, James, you're a funny
guy and a talented artist, and your
work in the past has been impressive. However, don't kid
yourself into thinking that you're
the end-all and be-all of political
commentary on this campus.
Your apology to your reading
public in your first letter was
ridiculous. Do you really believe
that anyone at Hopkins relied on
your cartoon every week? Don't
be silly. If it was there, they read
it. If it was funny, they laughed.
Otherwise, you went largely unnoticed. It's been tested, James—
very few people can remember on
Monday what your cartoon on
Friday was about without prompting. Besides which, if you
really wanted to provide for your
reading public after you left the
News-Letter, you could have
taken the Hopkins Spectator way
out, and postered campus, now
couldn't you?
As far as the censorship issue
goes, you weren't censored, you
were edited. I didn't see the cartoon, and quite frankly, I don't
care to see it. The fact of the matter is that you have been on staff
at the News-Letter for four years
now, and if you have any problem with the judgement of your
editors, you should have brought
it up before they were picked last
year. Obviously, the number of
people that feel as you do are in
the minority there, otherwise,
Brown and Engler would not be
where they are now. And if the
Lax player cartoon you published the week before all this started

was any indication, they probably
didn't edit you because of the
subject material, they probably
edited you because you weren't
funny.
This is not a dig, this is not an
insult, it's just a point. All the
comments made by the Lax coach
in the cartoon were hackneyed
stereotypical ideas that I have
heard since I got here, and the
drawing was redundant. I did not
fear for the social harmony of the
campus, I was not brought to
some as-yet-unequalled ire, I just
didn't laugh. It wasn't funny,
James.
You could argue, I suppose,
that you weren't trying to be funny, that you were making a social
commentary, a la Garry Trudeau
(parallel to be noted by the style
of the drawing). Well, Garry
Trudeau manages to be funny
when he makes his social commentary, and I have never known
Garry Trudeau to draw real people in his cartoon for the sole purpose of lambasting them, as you
have done in the past (George
Lerner, Andrea Perry, Steven
Muller, etc.). If this still does not
convince you, James, show the
cartoon to Mr. Trudeau when he
arrives in May and see what he
thinks.
But I digress. James, every
week, I turn in about 50-60 pages
of text, and I get edited down to
about three. I'm hurt, I feel
cheated, but I turn in a new column the next week. Brown and
Engler leave in what they think
will still be amusing, and
sometimes they're wrong. And,
if they decided to cut me
altogether one week, they would
do it. Such is life.
But then, no doubt you think
my column is useless fluff. And
you're right. I choose not to make
the sweeping and important
statements that you do. I would
imagine the whole approach to
your cartoon is different. Certainly you would not allow them to
hack one of your panels every
week. This is a given. Also, I
understand that each week,
Brown and Engler waited for you
to turn in your "cartoon."
Singular. That is, if they didn't
go with what you gave them, they
went with nothing. This was not
their doing, it was yours. You
might have given them an alternative, as the other writers at the
News-Letter do. But you don't.
You made editing, their job,
impossible.
James, why should you be the
only writer at the News-Letter not
subject to editing? The editors of
the News-Letter are faced with the
task of presenting an acceptable
News-Letter to a politically
volatile campus. With your last
cartoon, you presented them with
a no-win situation. Either the
presumed racial subject matter
would become the controversy,

or you would. Very clever on
your part, James, but it makes me
wonder whether you're reacting
this way because you truly feel
wronged or because you're upset
about being taken out of the
spotlight.
By the way, was that your
Valentine to the News-Letter in
last week's issue?
Christopher T. McColl

Free Speech
To the Editors:

As a relative newcomer to The
Johns Hopkins University, I
thought I might add perspective
on the controversies over "free
speech versus an offensive
message" debate. Before arriving at Hopkins in September, I
spent four years at Stanford
University, where a serious
debate concerning the same subject divided the campus along
similar lines. The main controversy was over whether the
University should allow students
with extremely offensive,
egregiously inappropriate opinions to proclaim their cretinous
stupidity in posters in university
dormitories. One specific case involved Ujaama, the Black theme
house, which found a defaced
poster of Beethoven (who it is
believed was partially Black) with
a racist epithet scrawled across
the front. Various campus
groups, most notably the
residents of the house, were appalled; "Clearly we do not have
to tolerate that sort of belittling,
defaming, racist-motivated, irrational attack on the grounds of
freedom of speech, do we?" they
asked in outrage.
Well, as a member of a leftwing coalition most likely to
agree with this point of view,
nonethless I personally must
disagree; we do have to tolerate
that sort of thing. The forum of
ideas that the various media provide us with should not be
regulated by the prevailing
fashion, or we may soon find our
opinions silenced as well. The
United States has not always been
a land where people could speak
out against established points of
view. A congressman from my
home state, J.Q. Adams
(previously U.S. President), was
repeatedly refused the right to
speak in Congress in the 1830's
and 40's against slavery. Adams
waged an unending, unsuccessful
battle against the infamous "gag
rule." His views were not allowed to be aired, because they offended the sensitivities of the
Southerners and their peculiar institution.
Nowadays, it is easy to say that
all races should be treated equally. To think otherwise is difficult,

not difficult to conclude which

Would you want Jane Fonda to
teach you how to read? Tender
tales of the middle-aged working
class are few and far between,
and for good reason: if they're
accurate, they're completely
uneventful. Martin Ritt's
"Stanley and Iris" is the latest
crack at this difficult nut—and as
far as nuts go, it's pretty
indigestible.
Robert DeNiro sheds his
palooka image to play Stanley
Cox, an illiterate cook who eventually loses his job due to his inability to read. Of course, he
wasn't having any problems at all
until the nosy Iris King (Jane
Fonda) put her two cents in.
Iris is recently widowed, raising her grade-school son (Harley
Cross) and budding daughter
(Martha Plimpton) on a pastry
and a prayer. If that weren't
enough, her oily sister Sharon
(Swoosie Kurtz) and her
whimpering husband Joe(Jamey
Sheridan) have moved in and do
everything but throw plates at
each other.
Iris works on a bakery
assembly line, smothering cakes
with icing or putting muffins into plastic containers. Fonda looks
better than ever, her eyes prac-

tically glowing, while everyone
else at the bakery looks like Roseanne Barr on a good day.
After befriending Stanley, she
troops in on a break to see if he
can give her some aspirin.
Stanley offers Rolaids, Flintsones, or whatever other small
aspirin-like bottles he can find.
Iris, that bastion of charm and unpredictability, says, "He can't
read!"
Stanley gets fired ("I could ask
you for seasoning salt and you
could bring back roach powder,"
his boss says), and all the usual
Down On Your Luck events
follow. He gets evicted, loses his
only friend (who happens to be
his father), and continues to
wander in a world he pretty much
can't understand.
A certain loss of identity comes
with illiteracy, and the finest
moments of "Stanley and Iris"
come when Stanley first tries to
convey his problem to Iris. He
cannot take the bus or get a
driver's license. He cannot open
a checking account. "Have I got
a name if! can't read it?" Stanley
asks.
Regrettably, that's about it as
far as deep meaning or audience
engagement. It is inherently difficult for the filmmakers to convey the challenge of illiteracy, or

E

for anyone to appreciate the scope
or nature of the problem. Stanley
and Iris proceed with the delicate
dance of his education, but the
film never really lives up to the
greatness of the problem.
There's more than a few
assembly line aspects to "Stanley
and Iris," beyond the fact that
they both work in a pastry factory. The screenplay, by Harriet
Frank and Irving Ravetch, has
"rewrite" written all over it.
Director Martin Ritt ("Norma
Rae," "Nuts")tries to nudge the
film along, but he elicits nothing
but the flattest of readings from
DeNiro and Fonda.
DeNiro has tried these roles
before, but Stanley Cox is simply a waste of his talent. (Did he
forget how to read in preparation
for this role'?) There's no rage or
passion in his work; it's practically numbing. As for the doe-eyed
Fonda, her melodramatics, unfortunately, fit the material.
Stanley's inevitable attachment
to Iris's son, like all other
subplots, is limited to one scene.
The sister and brother-in-law
disappear from the film about
halfway through. And Iris's unwed daughter, halfway through a
high school pregnancy, drops out
of school to begin working in the
factory. Huh? This film was

do and say and that's it, the end,
what happened, now what do you
think'?" We find similar craft and
invention in the wonderful "Arrangements," which spirals the
lives of its two lovers together
quickly and beautifully; in the terinsinuating
"The
ribly
Postcard," and in the book's final
story, the harrowing "Takes,"
where the implications of a random act of violence are detailed
meticulously from numerous
points of view. It is a virtuoso
piece of storytelling, and its
muted suggestion that love can
continue even in the maelstrom

Geology in the park
by Dan Grossman
On a cool November day, the
trees shedding their leaves for
winter, Professor Laurie Hardy
led eight geology students, myself
among them, into the depths of
Wyman Park, adjacent to the
Homewood Campus. Also with
us was our lab instructor, Lydon,
a graduate student originally from
Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Hardie
carried a shovel over his shoulder
as he led us students across the
dangerous San Martin Drive,
where cars swing around tight
curves at high velocities. In the
cloud-dampened light, with his
pointed gray beard and glasses,
he looked to me like a younger,
more intellectually vibrant version of Moses.
"This park's a refuge for kids
playing hookey as well as a place
of interest for geologists," he
said, revealing a dry, sardonic
wit.
As we descended on a dim path
through the woods at the park's
periphery, then crossed a bridge
over Stoney Run, the creek that
runs through the park, we saw
evidence that the park was indeed
a hangout for kids: a rope swing
tied to a tree over a stagnant pool
at streamside.
But the reason why we geo-lab
students (or pebble pups, as we
called ourselves) had come was
not immediately apparent; we had
to walk upstream along Stoney
Run in order to see the streambed and the slopes above where
beds of ancient basalts and
granites were formed more than
a billion years ago. The reason
we had come here, he said, was

because the Baltimore topography
yields little naturally exposed
bedrock. It is only along
streambeds where rocks, by a
stream's cutting action, become
exposed.
Hardie led us up along a badly
eroded streambank slope broken
by exposed tree roots and
weathered boulders. He walked
up to one of the boulders and we
gathered around. Hardie pushed
his shovel deep into what looked
like solid granite and then lifted
a shovelful of crumbled rock for
us students to inspect.
"It looks more like sand than
solid rock," said Hardie. In fact,
the material was rich in quartz,
the main component of beach
sand. He explained to us that the
decomposed rock we were looking at had been physically and
chemically weathered. The
material in the shovel, he said, is
an example of the first step of soil
formation. Then, after the rock
crumbles into its various components, it forms substances that
look more like soil than rock—
the second step of soil formation.
The best example of the
phenomenon was underfoot: the
orange clay-like substance that
covered most of the streamslope
and stuck to our sneakers when
we walked on it.
But Hardie could not point out
an example of the final step of soil
formation because there was no
topsoil to be found anywhere on
the streamslope. He explained
that the rapid streambank erosion
washes it all away before it can
form. "The whole slope's moving into the stream," he said.
As we walked farther up along

the streambed, we noticed other
minerals, besides quartz, that the
ancient rocks had decayed into.
Kate, a graduate student in the
Department of History, dug her
hands deep into a white powdery
substance formed by the chemical
decomposition of granite.
"That's Kaolin," Hardie said.
"You can put it in your
milkshakes, or if you have tummy trouble, swallow it."
Hardie was joking but only to
a point: the mineral kaolinite is
used by many fast-food chains as
a milk substitute in shakes. It is
also used in common digestive
remedies such a Kaopectate.
We then walked down from the
slope and out onto a dry portion
of the granitic streambed.
"Mainly, these rocks are
metamorphosed and altered
volcanic rocks," Hardie said,
pointing to the streambed.
"They're more than a billion
years old." Some of the students
were now scrambling off on their
own, identifying rocks and
minerals.
I peeled off a thin dark mineral
layer' off one of the streamed
rocks and asked, "Isn't that
mica?"
"That's right," Hardie said.
"It's biotite"(a dark, smokecolored mica). "Look over
there," he said, pointing to a pink
mineral about as big as a basketball embedded in the bedrock
nearby. "Can you guess what
that is?"
"Potassium feldspar?" said
Zenah Wilson, a senior History
of Science major.
"That's right," he said. "It's
a huge specimen."

In this light, scientists are now

especially those unaffected by
Western influences. He calls his
hypothesis the "core-fringelegume" pattern, or CFLP.
According to Dr. Mintz, the
staple of nearly every culture's
diet s is some starchy carbohydrate, providing about threequarters of the calorie intake.

Rifle captures fourth placetin MAC
sectionals, breaks 4,000-point mark
Courtesy of the rifle team
In a grueling three-hour, full
course match last weekend, the
varsity rifle team finished its
1989-90 season by placing fourth
of 14 teams in the Mid-Atlantic
Conference sectional tournament
in Philadelphia. For the second
time this season, the team scored
above the 4,000-point threshold
by shooting for 4,008 points out
of a possible 4,800.
All of the Hopkins shooters
performed well in the intense heat
and carbon-choked air of the
poorly ventilated indoor rifle
range. Senior Larry Young
finished his college career with a
strong 920 point match; junior
Matt Fisher and freshman Andy
Bernstein shot for 985 and 961
points, respectively. Senior Matt
Mayr, the team captain, fired for
1,002 points out of a possible
1,200, regaining his usual
number two position.
Senior Jim Kielkopf hoped to
beat 1,100 points and set a record
score in the last match of his college career. He was well on his
way to achieving that mark go-

ing into the last of his four standing targets.(One target contains
ten bulls, or a possible 100
points.) He had averaged in the
high 80s in his first three standing
targets, but with only three shots
left on the fourth target something
slipped, and Kielkopf let a shot
fly off target. The miss shattered
Kielkopf's mental composure,
and the loss of concentration and
confidence caused him to lost 20
out of 30 points over the last three
shots of standing positiondestroying his chance to beat
1,100 points. Kielkopf regained
his composure in kneeling position and fired two record targets
there, but he was forced to settle
for a final score of 1,060 pointsfar below his goal, but a strong
showing nonetheless.
The 1988-89 and 1989-90 rifle
teams have been the strongest
Hopkins teams in recent history.
Last year Hopkins came in second in the Mid-Atlantic Conference championship match, and
this year Hopkins shot its highest
scoring season ever. Much of this
has been due to the three strong
shooters in the Class of 1990.

Kielkopf, Mayr, and Young have
dominated the team in scoring
since shooting their way onto the
varsity squad their freshman year.
Their absence next year will
create a large void to be filled only by two experienced shooters.
Next year's team will be made up
mostly of freshmen of unknown
ability. However, the two returning shooters, Matt Fisher and
Andy Bernstein, have shown
remarkable improvement this
year, even challenging Mays and
Young for the number two and
three spots. Fisher is capable of
firing a 1,050 point match and
Bernstein, next year's captain,
should be able to shoot above
1,000 at the beginning of the
season.
Coach Sam Hardy was pleased with his team's accomplishments this year. "We
have had a rough season, with the
setbacks on the range and all,"
he said, "but we've done some
fine, fine shooting too. Next year
will be tougher . . . we have to
build a new team, but we are
looking forward to it."

Network counsels harrassment victims
by Priscilla O'Brian(
The Sexual Harassment Advisers Network is an informal
group of advisers that are there
to offer support. "We assist victims in exploring their options
and selecting one they are comfortable with and is most likely
to have the desired outcome. Our
main goal is bringing the offensive behavior to an end," said
Andrea Perry, director of
Residential Life and a member of
the Network.
The network uses an informal
resolution process,as its primary
role is as a support for the victim. According to Perry, "The
advisors are able to put victims
in touch with legal avenues and
make a referral to the appropriate
administrative office on campus
so that a formal complaint is
recorded."
"All the members of the Network have received some
training in the counseling of victims of harassment," according
to Perry. The main purpose of the
network "is to assist all members
of the [University] community
that feel that they have been sexually harassed or are uncertain
about whether they have been."
"The Network is very anxious
to publicize its existence and encourages members of the community who are confronting an

issue to take advantage of the support network," said Perry. She
went on to add, "Often times we
assist in figuring out whether or
not they have been harassed. In
many incidences, people are unsure if what has occurred is
harassment."
Sexual harassment is not
always as obvious as one would
believe. Harassment in the
university environment encompasses more than just requiring
sexual favors as a prerequisite for
academic success. It also comes
in many less blatant forms, including sexual teasing or jokes,
even slight physical contact.
Because sexual harassment does
come in many forms and varying
degrees, many people choose to
ignore it, fearing they may be
wrong; others are sure, but are
too embarrassed to talk with
anyone about it. According to
Perry, there is nothing to fear or
be embarrassed over; everyone
has the right to pursue their
education in a conducive atmosphere. In reporting sexual
harassment one is merely asserting the rights one has under
University policy as well as state
law.
The University has a strict
policy on sexual harassment: any
conduct "which creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive
learning or working environment

is prohibited. The University will
promptly investigate complaints
of sexual harassment and . . . will
institute disciplinary proceedings
against the offending individual."
Also, according to Perry,"The
Advisors Network is not primarily designed to help victims of
assault or rape." It is suggested
that if one is assaulted that one
contact either campus security or
the police immediately and seek
medical attention. There are
many victim assistance programs
in the area and, professional
counseling is also available on
campus at the White House.

The Community Assistants
on the Wolman Renovations
It has long been recognized that
the University has not established the concerns of undergraduate
life at Hopkins as its primary
focus. Recently, this prevailing
attitude has been made evident by
the minimal involvement of
University-owned apartment
residents in the decision making
process regarding University
apartment renovations. The committees set up to discuss these
renovations included administrators from the Offices of
Residential Life, Auxiliary Enterprises, Housing, Facilities
Management, and the Dean of
Students. Initially, when this
comprehensive committee met,
resident input was not effectively utilized. As far as can be
discerned, no appropriate resident
representatives were included in
the planning process. In fact, the
students on the original committee were chosen specifically
because they lived in off-campus
housing and were hand-picked by
the administration. As a result,
these students considered only the
disadvantages of living in University housing. In making changes
that affect resident life, those
students most directly affected
should have been consulted on a
much larger scale. Specifically,
students living in Universityowned apartments would have
been an ideal choice for additional student representation for
this comprehensive committee.
Community Assistants, working for the Housing Office and
the Office of Residential Life,
have as one of their major responsibilities the role of liason between the University-owned apartment residents and the administrators of the Homewood
campus for housing-related concerns. In light of this responssibility, it would have been appropriate to include Community
Assistants on the committee for
University apartment renovations. Because of this omission,
ideas form residents were not
considered. The following are
concerns relayed to Community

Assistants by current University
apartment residents with regards
to the soon-to-be-available Bradford Apartments.
(1) Students will be held
responsible for the entire apartment lease, paying per unit instead of the current method of
paying per bed.
(2) Eventual plans include forcing the tenant to commit to a
12-month lease instead of the current 9-month lease option.
(3) Students will be responsible for arranging their own
utilities. This will be an additional expense not accounted for
in the rent.
(4) Rental price estimates have
yet to be released for students and
their parents.
Some other concerns, in
general, about the proposed
University apartment renovations
are as follows:
(1) More apartment units
should have been designated as
single-occupancy dwellings.
(2) Attention should have been
paid more to the overall quality
of student life than to the maximum number of students housed together.
(3) The current question over
mandated versus guaranteed
sophomore housing in the
renovated Wolman and McCoy
Apartments should be answered
only after consulting students
most affected by the plans.
These are just a few of the ideas
that have yet to be addresses
satisfactorily. Future renovation
plans must resolve these issues.
Clearly student involvement at all
levels is crucial in planning for
resident life. It is not sufficient for
only students outside of University housing to participate in the
decision making process.

To the Editors:
In response to the article written by Rebecca Garron which appeared in the last issue of the
News-Letter: Ms. Garron states
that the intention of her discourse
is to defend the 2x +1 cartoon
from "misdirected, impassioned
criticism." She begins her
defense by questioning whether
or not the cartoon, a cartoon
which seeks to define a woman's
merit solely on the basis of her
sexual attractiveness, is sexist.
The call for "all hate mail"
scrawled beneath the cartoon
underscores the fact that the
author's primary intention was to
offend. Mr. Podurgiel requested
a response; I think he is getting
that for which he asked.
Ms. Garron goes on to
enumerate the responsibilities of
the Hopkins community. She
states that censorship in not the
answer. She is completely correct. To address the issue at hand.
when we, not the Women's
Group but for Hopkins students,
spoke to Dean Boswell, our intentions were as follows. We
wanted a letter to be distributed
to all students by Homewood
Deans stating that sexism should
not be tolerated on the campus.
Secondly, we wanted a meeting
arranged between the Spectator,
the GRO, and the concerned
students so that we could determine the positions of all involved, why the GRO allocated
University funds to support this
issue of the Spectator, and
whether the GRO was aware of
the cartoon in question.
It was not these four students
but Ms. Garron herself who calls
for the SAC to "pull its funding
from the Spectator." It seems that
Ms. Garron did not bother to
gather the correct information
before she began her tirade. Firstly, it was not a "special-interest
group" which filed the complaint
against the Spectator but four
students, two of whom were
unaffiliated. Secondly, the goal of
these students was not to stifle but
to draw out the issue of sexism.
Thirdly, the Spectator is not funded by the SAC but an outside
organization. It was granted funds
for only this issue by the GRO,
thus her call for SAC funding to
be denied, besides suggesting
censorship, is useless.
To continue with Ms. Garron's
list of reponsibilities: under item
number two, she attempts to shift
the "blame" for this cartoon
from the cartoonist to the Spectator. My questions to Rebecca
Garron: Is the Spectator some
amorphous mass? Is it not made
up of its contributors? Do they
have no responsibility for their
submissions?
The list is concluded with item

number three, in which Ms. Garron attempts to redefine the
definition of special interest
groups, claiming that all groups
should be dedicated to combatting
"all issues which divide the community." Perhaps Ms. Garron is
the only student who has the time
and energy to devote to every
issue on campus; the fact that
most students are busy with
classes, etc. is the reason why
responsibilities are divided.
Ms. Garron does make one
useful comment: "if we can't
eradicate prejudice in the containment of academia, we will be
unable to hinder its reproduction
in society at large." This is our
overall goal, not censorship, but
increased awareness and eventual
defeat of the prejudices that are
prevalent on the campus and in
society. Perhaps Ms. Garron and
others like her should stop to
assess the correct information
from "misdirected, impassioned
criticism."
Kelly King

Dear James
To the Editors:
At the risk of joining what I
think is a senseless enterprise, I
have a few things I'd like to bring
up.
Look, James, you're a funny
guy and a talented artist, and your
work in the past has been impressive. However, don't kid
yourself into thinking that you're
the end-all and be-all of political
commentary on this campus.
Your apology to your reading
public in your first letter was
ridiculous. Do you really believe
that anyone at Hopkins relied on
your cartoon every week? Don't
be silly. If it was there, they read
it. If it was funny, they laughed.
Otherwise, you went largely unnoticed. It's been tested, James—
very few people can remember on
Monday what your cartoon on
Friday was about without prompting. Besides which, if you
really wanted to provide for your
reading public after you left the
News-Letter, you could have
taken the Hopkins Spectator way
out, and postered campus, now
couldn't you?
As far as the censorship issue
goes, you weren't censored, you
were edited. I didn't see the cartoon, and quite frankly, I don't
care to see it. The fact of the matter is that you have been on staff
at the News-Letter for four years
now, and if you have any problem with the judgement of your
editors, you should have brought
it up before they were picked last
year. Obviously, the number of
people that feel as you do are in
the minority there, otherwise,
Brown and Engler would not be
where they are now. And if the
Lax player cartoon you published the week before all this started

was any indication, they probably
didn't edit you because of the
subject material, they probably
edited you because you weren't
funny.
This is not a dig, this is not an
insult, it's just a point. All the
comments made by the Lax coach
in the cartoon were hackneyed
stereotypical ideas that I have
heard since I got here, and the
drawing was redundant. I did not
fear for the social harmony of the
campus, I was not brought to
some as-yet-unequalled ire, I just
didn't laugh. It wasn't funny,
James.
You could argue, I suppose,
that you weren't trying to be funny, that you were making a social
commentary, a la Garry Trudeau
(parallel to be noted by the style
of the drawing). Well, Garry
Trudeau manages to be funny
when he makes his social commentary, and I have never known
Garry Trudeau to draw real people in his cartoon for the sole purpose of lambasting them, as you
have done in the past (George
Lerner, Andrea Perry, Steven
Muller, etc.). If this still does not
convince you, James, show the
cartoon to Mr. Trudeau when he
arrives in May and see what he
thinks.
But I digress. James, every
week, I turn in about 50-60 pages
of text, and I get edited down to
about three. I'm hurt, I feel
cheated, but I turn in a new column the next week. Brown and
Engler leave in what they think
will still be amusing, and
sometimes they're wrong. And,
if they decided to cut me
altogether one week, they would
do it. Such is life.
But then, no doubt you think
my column is useless fluff. And
you're right. I choose not to make
the sweeping and important
statements that you do. I would
imagine the whole approach to
your cartoon is different. Certainly you would not allow them to
hack one of your panels every
week. This is a given. Also, I
understand that each week,
Brown and Engler waited for you
to turn in your "cartoon."
Singular. That is, if they didn't
go with what you gave them, they
went with nothing. This was not
their doing, it was yours. You
might have given them an alternative, as the other writers at the
News-Letter do. But you don't.
You made editing, their job,
impossible.
James, why should you be the
only writer at the News-Letter not
subject to editing? The editors of
the News-Letter are faced with the
task of presenting an acceptable
News-Letter to a politically
volatile campus. With your last
cartoon, you presented them with
a no-win situation. Either the
presumed racial subject matter
would become the controversy,

or you would. Very clever on
your part, James, but it makes me
wonder whether you're reacting
this way because you truly feel
wronged or because you're upset
about being taken out of the
spotlight.
By the way, was that your
Valentine to the News-Letter in
last week's issue?
Christopher T. McColl

Free Speech
To the Editors:

As a relative newcomer to The
Johns Hopkins University, I
thought I might add perspective
on the controversies over "free
speech versus an offensive
message" debate. Before arriving at Hopkins in September, I
spent four years at Stanford
University, where a serious
debate concerning the same subject divided the campus along
similar lines. The main controversy was over whether the
University should allow students
with extremely offensive,
egregiously inappropriate opinions to proclaim their cretinous
stupidity in posters in university
dormitories. One specific case involved Ujaama, the Black theme
house, which found a defaced
poster of Beethoven (who it is
believed was partially Black) with
a racist epithet scrawled across
the front. Various campus
groups, most notably the
residents of the house, were appalled; "Clearly we do not have
to tolerate that sort of belittling,
defaming, racist-motivated, irrational attack on the grounds of
freedom of speech, do we?" they
asked in outrage.
Well, as a member of a leftwing coalition most likely to
agree with this point of view,
nonethless I personally must
disagree; we do have to tolerate
that sort of thing. The forum of
ideas that the various media provide us with should not be
regulated by the prevailing
fashion, or we may soon find our
opinions silenced as well. The
United States has not always been
a land where people could speak
out against established points of
view. A congressman from my
home state, J.Q. Adams
(previously U.S. President), was
repeatedly refused the right to
speak in Congress in the 1830's
and 40's against slavery. Adams
waged an unending, unsuccessful
battle against the infamous "gag
rule." His views were not allowed to be aired, because they offended the sensitivities of the
Southerners and their peculiar institution.
Nowadays, it is easy to say that
all races should be treated equally. To think otherwise is difficult,

On Feb. 22nd, George Bush is
slated to speak at Hopkins' Commemoration Day exercises, and
to receive an honorary degree.
The irony of this has thus far
caused very little controversy on
the Homewood Campus, considering that this is an institute of
higher learning whose fame has
come primarily from advancing
medical knowledge and human
health.
This man, who in cahoots with
his predecessor, has wrought
havoc on higher education and
health care in this country, is going to receive the highest accolade that this university has to
offer. His 1990 budget proposal
allocated less than 8% for all
health and education programs
combined (1.5 billion dollars less
than the 1990 budget proposed by
the Reagan administration!). In
spite of all of the events in the
world over the past year, his 1991
budget proposes increasing the
military budget again, while funding for higher education loan
programs will be cut, again. This
man's sole public health accomplishment has been to create
public hysteria over illegal drug
consumption, at a time when illegal drug death rates and addiction rates are at their lowest in 15
years. (According to former
Surgeon General Koop, in 1988
there were about 2,000 cocaine
related deaths in the U.S. and
390,000 deaths from tobacco.) At
the same time, the Reagan and
Bush administrations have been

relentless in their political arm
twisting in order to open foreign
markets to tobacco imports (i.e.
Thailand). The domestic health
policies of the past decade have
allowed such places as Italy, East
Germany, and Hong Kong to surpass the U.S. with regard to infant survival rates.
Hopkins has had a somewhat
schizophrenic face since it was
founded by a liquor-running
Quaker. Today these faces remain, personified by A.P.L. and
Hopkins' notoriously cutthroat
fiscal policies(as recently criticized in the Wall Street Journal), and
personifying the other face, as the
host of the Albert Schweitzer
Award for Humanitarianism, and
by the University's fundraising
efforts for the United Way. It is
not difficult to conclude which
face has invited Mr. Bush.
Les Roberts

Forgettable 'Stanley and Iris'
Like a Cinematic Jail Term
by Mark Friedman
Would you want Jane Fonda to
teach you how to read? Tender
tales of the middle-aged working
class are few and far between,
and for good reason: if they're
accurate, they're completely
uneventful. Martin Ritt's
"Stanley and Iris" is the latest
crack at this difficult nut—and as
far as nuts go, it's pretty
indigestible.
Robert DeNiro sheds his
palooka image to play Stanley
Cox, an illiterate cook who eventually loses his job due to his inability to read. Of course, he
wasn't having any problems at all
until the nosy Iris King (Jane
Fonda) put her two cents in.
Iris is recently widowed, raising her grade-school son (Harley
Cross) and budding daughter
(Martha Plimpton) on a pastry
and a prayer. If that weren't
enough, her oily sister Sharon
(Swoosie Kurtz) and her
whimpering husband Joe(Jamey
Sheridan) have moved in and do
everything but throw plates at
each other.
Iris works on a bakery
assembly line, smothering cakes
with icing or putting muffins into plastic containers. Fonda looks
better than ever, her eyes prac-

MO

V

I

tically glowing, while everyone
else at the bakery looks like Roseanne Barr on a good day.
After befriending Stanley, she
troops in on a break to see if he
can give her some aspirin.
Stanley offers Rolaids, Flintsones, or whatever other small
aspirin-like bottles he can find.
Iris, that bastion of charm and unpredictability, says, "He can't
read!"
Stanley gets fired ("I could ask
you for seasoning salt and you
could bring back roach powder,"
his boss says), and all the usual
Down On Your Luck events
follow. He gets evicted, loses his
only friend (who happens to be
his father), and continues to
wander in a world he pretty much
can't understand.
A certain loss of identity comes
with illiteracy, and the finest
moments of "Stanley and Iris"
come when Stanley first tries to
convey his problem to Iris. He
cannot take the bus or get a
driver's license. He cannot open
a checking account. "Have I got
a name if! can't read it?" Stanley
asks.
Regrettably, that's about it as
far as deep meaning or audience
engagement. It is inherently difficult for the filmmakers to convey the challenge of illiteracy, or

E

for anyone to appreciate the scope
or nature of the problem. Stanley
and Iris proceed with the delicate
dance of his education, but the
film never really lives up to the
greatness of the problem.
There's more than a few
assembly line aspects to "Stanley
and Iris," beyond the fact that
they both work in a pastry factory. The screenplay, by Harriet
Frank and Irving Ravetch, has
"rewrite" written all over it.
Director Martin Ritt ("Norma
Rae," "Nuts")tries to nudge the
film along, but he elicits nothing
but the flattest of readings from
DeNiro and Fonda.
DeNiro has tried these roles
before, but Stanley Cox is simply a waste of his talent. (Did he
forget how to read in preparation
for this role'?) There's no rage or
passion in his work; it's practically numbing. As for the doe-eyed
Fonda, her melodramatics, unfortunately, fit the material.
Stanley's inevitable attachment
to Iris's son, like all other
subplots, is limited to one scene.
The sister and brother-in-law
disappear from the film about
halfway through. And Iris's unwed daughter, halfway through a
high school pregnancy, drops out
of school to begin working in the
factory. Huh? This film was

S

Robert DeNiro and Jane Fonda in "Stanley and Iris"
edited with a hatchet.
In an effort to make the
characters stand out from their
montonous nine-to-five existence,
they either say things that are
unbelievably stupid or embarassingly profound. It's awkward in
either case. When the family
starts to act up at the dinner table,
Iris chides her sister, "We're all
in the same lifeboat—don't rock
it." This is one adult talking to
another!
"Stanley and Iris" makes such
an effort to stress the
incarceration-like aspects of the
character's lives that any attempts
to inflate them beyond ordinary
stature seems akin to glorifying
criminals. Everyone hates his

job, yearns for more self-esteem,
and something beyond the
assembly line.
"This is my prison," the
characters repeatedly insist. But

in this battle of boredom, the audience is likely to emerge the
prisoner cramped in an uncomfortable theater chair during this
forgettable film.

Geology in the park
by Dan Grossman
On a cool November day, the
trees shedding their leaves for
winter, Professor Laurie Hardy
led eight geology students, myself
among them, into the depths of
Wyman Park, adjacent to the
Homewood Campus. Also with
us was our lab instructor, Lydon,
a graduate student originally from
Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Hardie
carried a shovel over his shoulder
as he led us students across the
dangerous San Martin Drive,
where cars swing around tight
curves at high velocities. In the
cloud-dampened light, with his
pointed gray beard and glasses,
he looked to me like a younger,
more intellectually vibrant version of Moses.
"This park's a refuge for kids
playing hookey as well as a place
of interest for geologists," he
said, revealing a dry, sardonic
wit.
As we descended on a dim path
through the woods at the park's
periphery, then crossed a bridge
over Stoney Run, the creek that
runs through the park, we saw
evidence that the park was indeed
a hangout for kids: a rope swing
tied to a tree over a stagnant pool
at streamside.
But the reason why we geo-lab
students (or pebble pups, as we
called ourselves) had come was
not immediately apparent; we had
to walk upstream along Stoney
Run in order to see the streambed and the slopes above where
beds of ancient basalts and
granites were formed more than
a billion years ago. The reason
we had come here, he said, was

because the Baltimore topography
yields little naturally exposed
bedrock. It is only along
streambeds where rocks, by a
stream's cutting action, become
exposed.
Hardie led us up along a badly
eroded streambank slope broken
by exposed tree roots and
weathered boulders. He walked
up to one of the boulders and we
gathered around. Hardie pushed
his shovel deep into what looked
like solid granite and then lifted
a shovelful of crumbled rock for
us students to inspect.
"It looks more like sand than
solid rock," said Hardie. In fact,
the material was rich in quartz,
the main component of beach
sand. He explained to us that the
decomposed rock we were looking at had been physically and
chemically weathered. The
material in the shovel, he said, is
an example of the first step of soil
formation. Then, after the rock
crumbles into its various components, it forms substances that
look more like soil than rock—
the second step of soil formation.
The best example of the
phenomenon was underfoot: the
orange clay-like substance that
covered most of the streamslope
and stuck to our sneakers when
we walked on it.
But Hardie could not point out
an example of the final step of soil
formation because there was no
topsoil to be found anywhere on
the streamslope. He explained
that the rapid streambank erosion
washes it all away before it can
form. "The whole slope's moving into the stream," he said.
As we walked farther up along

the streambed, we noticed other
minerals, besides quartz, that the
ancient rocks had decayed into.
Kate, a graduate student in the
Department of History, dug her
hands deep into a white powdery
substance formed by the chemical
decomposition of granite.
"That's Kaolin," Hardie said.
"You can put it in your
milkshakes, or if you have tummy trouble, swallow it."
Hardie was joking but only to
a point: the mineral kaolinite is
used by many fast-food chains as
a milk substitute in shakes. It is
also used in common digestive
remedies such a Kaopectate.
We then walked down from the
slope and out onto a dry portion
of the granitic streambed.
"Mainly, these rocks are
metamorphosed and altered
volcanic rocks," Hardie said,
pointing to the streambed.
"They're more than a billion
years old." Some of the students
were now scrambling off on their
own, identifying rocks and
minerals.
I peeled off a thin dark mineral
layer' off one of the streamed
rocks and asked, "Isn't that
mica?"
"That's right," Hardie said.
"It's biotite"(a dark, smokecolored mica). "Look over
there," he said, pointing to a pink
mineral about as big as a basketball embedded in the bedrock
nearby. "Can you guess what
that is?"
"Potassium feldspar?" said
Zenah Wilson, a senior History
of Science major.
"That's right," he said. "It's
a huge specimen."

UAA and MAC Player of the Week Andy Enfield splits a pair of Case
Western defenders in action last Friday at the Athletic Center. Enfield
led all scorers with 27 points, as the Jays coasted to an 88-71 victory.

The Blue Jays have been
eliminated from post-season play.
Or have they? With a 5-4 record
in the MAC Southeast division
and one game to play, Hopkins
stands a game and a half behind
second-place Widener. Even
should Widener lose its final two
games and Hopkins upset
Washington College, the Jays
would lose the tiebreaker by virtue of losing to Widener twice.
However, the Jays have an
overall record of 16-7, which
might be good enough to catch
the eye of Division III tournament
officials and secure an "at large"
bid. The Jays would need a win
over Washington College tomorrow to have any chance of being
selected by the tournament committee. Washington has been
ranked as high as seventeenth in

Hopkins 78-76 on two free

Finishing with a 17-7 record

committee, but Hopkins does not
have a particularly strong basketball tradition, a factor which

sometimes helps perennially good
teams get selected even when
they have a mediocre year.
However. the Jays' chances are
buoyed by their second consecutive winning season and their
tough schedule. "Four of our
seven losses have been to teams
ranked in the [national] top twenty," pointed out Coach Bill
Nelson. In addition, the team is
finishing strong, having won four
straight and six of their last seven.

UAA rivals, Washington University and Case Western Reserve
University. The Washington
game was expected to be close,
but the Jays took an early lead and
raced to a 43-28 halftime edge.

a 73-69 victory. Despite the slim
final margin, the Jays were never
really threatened. Their only
liability was their free-throw
shooting, which allowed

close at the end. Hopkins finished 9-17 from the line for 53 percent. The team actually shot better from the field, ending up
30-52 for 58 percent.

Washington was unable to stop
Andy Enfield, who continued his
hot shooting with a 9-of-13 performance, including three of five

scored 16 points on 8-of-10

favorite spot on the left baseline.
Dave Eikenberg had six assists,
two steals, and only one turnover.
Jay Gangemi added 13 for the

nine rebounds. Gangemi leads

makes up for his lack of size with
quickness and tenacity, as well as

was, because he came out firing
in the first half, pumping in 15
points, mostly on turnaround
jumpers. He finished with 21 and

Squash sweeps through Howe Cup undefeated
Completes season with best-ever championships showing
by Jerry Irvine
With a spotless 5-0 record, the
women's squash team came away
from this year's national championships at Yale with its best
showing ever. The team competed in the fourth division, and
surprised almost everyone at the
Howe Cup by tying Smith College for top honors. The tournament is divided into four divisions, with teams being seeded
according to their records and
level of competition throughout
the year. Hopkins was seeded
25th out of 26 teams, yet managed to come out of the weekend

competition with a perfect record.
"The team really performed
beyond the expectations of many
people," stated Frank Cushman,
who along with his wife Nancy
are in their first year as coaches
at Hopkins. He went on to say
that the fact that the team defeated
three teams at the Howe Cup that
had defeated them earlier in the
year really illustrates the amount
of improvement the team has
undergone.
The Jays arrived at Yale last
Friday and began preparing for
their first match against
Wesleyan. Said sophomore
Jessica Trcp p, "We came into

the tournament a little skeptical,
but we had a good overall
attitude—we had nothing to lose
and nowhere to go but up."
Echoing these sentiments, senior
captain Kathryn Ng stated,"We
decided to take each match one
at a time." The positive attitude
paid off, as the squad posted a 7-2
victory over Wesleyan.
This victory is made even more
impressive when one considers
that Wesleyan beat Hopkins 7-2
earlier in the year. Later, on Friday, the team beat Bates 6-3, a
team they had lost to 5-4 earlier
in the season. "After those two
wins on Friday against the top-

seeded teams, we began to realize
we had a good chance of winning our division," stated Tropp.
Saturday started with an impressive 8-1 victory over Mt.
Holyoke College. The team carried their gathering momentum
into the fourth match against
Connecticut College and came
away with a 6-3 victory. On Sunday the team trounced Haverford
for the second time this year with
a 7-2 score. "The bottom half of
our line-up really came through
for us," stated Frank Cushman.
In fact, the fourth through seventh
ranked players went undefeated
throughout the entire tournament.

"We are a very even team, which
allows us to win many matches
because other teams don't usually have as strong a bottom half as
we do," continued Cushman.
Hopkins' showing at the tournament is surprising due to the
young and inexperienced squad
they carry. Seven out of the nine
players on the team are either
sophomores or freshmen, and
many players have only a year or
two of court experience. Most of
the teams Hopkins faced were
comprised ofjuniors and seniors

Women fencers remain at .500
by Bill Berger
The Hopkins women's fencing
team suffered losses Saturday to
William Patterson and host
Brooklyn College. The team also
salvaged one win against Goucher
College to remain at .500 for the
season with a 4-4 record.
The team lost to a very experienced William Patterson
squad, 4-12 in the day's first
meet. Defeat was expected, as
William Patterson traditionally
boasts a strong squad.
Against home team Brooklyn
College, in the day's second
meet, the women suffered a letdown resulting in a 6-10 loss.
Head coach Gary Green attributed the team's disappointing
performance against Brooklyn
College to the scheduling of the
meets. "The team lost some confidence after facing William Patterson to start the day. We should
have done better."
The female fencers rebounded
to defeat Goucher College, 10-6.
in the day's final meet. The win
evened the team's overall record,
giving them a reasonable shot at
finishing above .500 for the
season, a marked improvement
over last year's mark.
Freshman Kerni Hren and
sophomore Ruth Ochia compete
at USFA National Junior Olym-

pic championships in Chicago
this weekend while the remainder
of the team enjoys a welldeserved break after eight meets
in four weeks.
Senior captain Domenica
Rotunda continues to enjoy her
best season ever, leading the team
with a 16-11 bout record. Green
commented, "Domenica is really starting to put it all together this
year. It's nice to see her doing so
well since she learned how to
fence here at Hopkins." Rotunda is the team's only senior.
Coming up the weekend of
February 24-25, the women
fencers host the UAA Championships. Odds are on favorite New
York University, who beat the
Hopkins women in a heartbreaker
last season. Green expects to
challenge Brandeis University for
second place in the tournament.
The men's fencing team hiked its
record to 13-2 overall, 10-1 conference, with four victories Saturday at the New Jersey Institute of
Technology. The sabre team continued to dominate and remains
undefeated.
In the first meet, Blue Jay
fencers trounced home team
NJIT, 20-7 (14-4). The epee team
led the route by sweeping opponents, 9-0.

Rifle captures fourth placetin MAC
sectionals, breaks 4,000-point mark
Courtesy of the rifle team
In a grueling three-hour, full
course match last weekend, the
varsity rifle team finished its
1989-90 season by placing fourth
of 14 teams in the Mid-Atlantic
Conference sectional tournament
in Philadelphia. For the second
time this season, the team scored
above the 4,000-point threshold
by shooting for 4,008 points out
of a possible 4,800.
All of the Hopkins shooters
performed well in the intense heat
and carbon-choked air of the
poorly ventilated indoor rifle
range. Senior Larry Young
finished his college career with a
strong 920 point match; junior
Matt Fisher and freshman Andy
Bernstein shot for 985 and 961
points, respectively. Senior Matt
Mayr, the team captain, fired for
1,002 points out of a possible
1,200, regaining his usual
number two position.
Senior Jim Kielkopf hoped to
beat 1,100 points and set a record
score in the last match of his college career. He was well on his
way to achieving that mark go-

ing into the last of his four standing targets.(One target contains
ten bulls, or a possible 100
points.) He had averaged in the
high 80s in his first three standing
targets, but with only three shots
left on the fourth target something
slipped, and Kielkopf let a shot
fly off target. The miss shattered
Kielkopf's mental composure,
and the loss of concentration and
confidence caused him to lost 20
out of 30 points over the last three
shots of standing positiondestroying his chance to beat
1,100 points. Kielkopf regained
his composure in kneeling position and fired two record targets
there, but he was forced to settle
for a final score of 1,060 pointsfar below his goal, but a strong
showing nonetheless.
The 1988-89 and 1989-90 rifle
teams have been the strongest
Hopkins teams in recent history.
Last year Hopkins came in second in the Mid-Atlantic Conference championship match, and
this year Hopkins shot its highest
scoring season ever. Much of this
has been due to the three strong
shooters in the Class of 1990.

Kielkopf, Mayr, and Young have
dominated the team in scoring
since shooting their way onto the
varsity squad their freshman year.
Their absence next year will
create a large void to be filled only by two experienced shooters.
Next year's team will be made up
mostly of freshmen of unknown
ability. However, the two returning shooters, Matt Fisher and
Andy Bernstein, have shown
remarkable improvement this
year, even challenging Mays and
Young for the number two and
three spots. Fisher is capable of
firing a 1,050 point match and
Bernstein, next year's captain,
should be able to shoot above
1,000 at the beginning of the
season.
Coach Sam Hardy was pleased with his team's accomplishments this year. "We
have had a rough season, with the
setbacks on the range and all,"
he said, "but we've done some
fine, fine shooting too. Next year
will be tougher . . . we have to
build a new team, but we are
looking forward to it."
